subject: Welcome to Piazza!
content:
Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started:
  1. Ask questions! The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are).
  2. Edit questions and answers wiki-style. Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors’ answer for instructors).
  3. Add a followup to comment or ask further questions. To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above.
  4. Go anonymous. Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously.
  5. Tag your posts. It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag.
  6. Format code and equations. Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation.
  7. View and download class details and resources.
Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place! Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at team@piazza.com. We love feedback!

subject: [WEEK 1] Welcome to Snap!
content: Please post questions related to the 'Welcome to Snap!' portion of this week's problem set below.

I am a bit confused about the last section of the this problem set about making a kaleidoscope. Do I need to know how to get all four sprites to draw at once like the animation shows? Also, which scripts do I need to use to get the sprites to go in different directions?

Not sure about your first question, but as to how to get the sprites to go in different directions I found it helpful to think of it as a reflection on a graph. For example, if the red sprite starts on a graph at (-10,5), then a green sprite who will be reflected across the y-axis will start at (10,5). This means that for the green sprite to follow the mouse, it won't follow the exact coordinates as the red one would, but reflected coordinates (negative and/or shifted). I hope that makes sense.
Thank you so much! That helped me a lot.

subject: [WEEK 1] Build your own blocks
content: Please post questions related to the 'Build your own blocks' portion of this week's problem set below.

You can go to File>Open> and then find where you saved the xml file and it should pull it up. You can also drag the file onto the Snap! stage.

I managed to make my program draw beautiful little random flowers. Now, all flowers are lovely, but some more than others :D However, it is not easy to replicate certain shapes manually. Is there a way my function can tell me which random numbers it picked for its last operation?

That's a great idea! I'd suggest adding in a list component! Not sure if this has been covered in class yet but it's not difficult to implement!

Make a new variable that is an empty list. Use the "add -thing/number- to -nameOfList-", taking care to insert the correct variables in and place it appropriately in your code for the random flowers block so it occurs with each repetition. As long as the list is a global variable, you should be able to view the list of numbers by clicking on the variable on the side under the Variables tab. Alternatively, click the check box next to the variable so it is displayed on the playing screen. If you have any questions about this, feel free to follow up!

subject: Welcome to CS10 Piazza Page!

This page will function as our online message board for CS10 Summer 2020. Here, you can post questions related to any aspect of the course and interact with staff and fellow students while you work through the material. subject: Clarifications on Lecture and Course Communications
content:
Hello everyone!

Just wanted to officially clarify questions regarding Lecture, syllabus, and the website. 

When is Lecture?

Lectures will be held Monday through Thursdays each at 9am. CalCentral lists 4-5pm because that was the time we were arbitrarily given, but we found that 9am is a time that best accommodates all students in the course given differences in time zones. Please ignore anything listed in CalCentral/Canvas.

Where do I find the Syllabus?

The syllabus can be found here in google doc form, or here on the website. Why is it not on Canvas? That'll be clarified in the next section.

Canvas???

We don't really use Canvas in this class. The syllabus goes into more detail about official course platforms, but essentially we use Piazza for course communications, the course website to access course content, and Gradescope to release grades.

First Lecture?

The first lecture isn't content-related, as it's more of a syllabus day/running through the platforms we've discussed so far. It'll also be a chance for our staff to introduce themselves and field any initial questions you may have about the course's day-to-day flow. That being said, we'll be getting up the related videos up in the next day or so for the course.

Okay... I looked at everything above but my question still wasn't answered!

Sorry about that :c. But I do recommend asking any further questions you have on Piazza, or directly emailing me, Aaron, or one of our TAs if it's really urgent. Asking questions on Piazza is pretty nice because other classmates might have that same question and they'll appreciate it. Otherwise, you can find our emails here on the website. You can also read our bios (except mine, please don't click on mine).
Just to reiterate: here is the Zoom link for lecture! http://bjc.link/cs10su20

subject: Note Taking
content:
What type of notes, e.g. on a computer or on paper, etc., would people, particularly those who have already taken this course, recommend? Also, do you recommend that we take notes on video lectures and/or class discussions?

Thank you!

Personally, I only highlighted and took marginal notes for lectures, but I tried really really hard on the psets and projects.

Like martial arts, CS is best learned by doing. The lectures will introduce you to concepts, but actually practicing coding will help ingrain them into your mind better. 

Discussions will have a short recap lecture, but will focus on a worksheet with practice problems. When you don't understand why an answer is correct (or even why an incorrect answer is wrong), please ask. Chances are that you are not the only one who is unsure. Try another practice question. Repeat.

When it comes to exams, doing practice ones has shown to be one of the most effective ways of studying.

If, at any point in this course, you feel you are not learning, contact a TA. We're more than happy to give you pointers!

subject: Missed first class
content:
Hello,

I accidentally missed today's class because I thought it would be at 4PM PST rather than 9AM today. Is there any chance I can watch a recorded zoom lecture of today's meeting? Also, from now on, will we be emailed a zoom link every day for the next lecture?

Thank you!
I don’t think the lecture was recorded, however, we just went over syllabus and then did some work during lab. They said zoom link will always be the same. Here is the zoom link: bjc.link/cs10su20

To add on to the student answer, even if you missed the first lecture you can watch the videos we've recorded as they essentially cover the same content we've discussed in lecture today. In future lectures, it will be expected that you've seen the webcasts prior to attending because they will focus more on reviewing/recapping the content talked about in the videos vs. introducing it for the first time.

1. Does the live session from Monday -Wednesday will NEVER be recorded? And if we miss a session, we should watch the video series to make up the content. Is that correct?

2. The Thursday live session is where we will get credit for the SI part and it is 25 pt? And the Friday check-in will worth another 25 pt?

3. Does the attendance for discussion sessions are weekly or daily? How does the attendance affect the grade? Is it ok if I go to discussion one a week or do I need to attend all of the sessions through the week?

4. Which compiler should I use for python? Especially for MAC? 

Sorry for the long list 

Thank you!

Hello there!

I'll answer these in order.

1. We will be recording these sessions! Although we forgot to do so today :c
2. SI sessions are worth 25 points collectively. There are 6 SI sessions so they're worth roughly ~4 points each.
3. Attendance is handled per TA, as it's not any points out of your grade. However, it is possible to earn EPA (extra credit) points by showing up regularly. The attendance that your discussion TAs collect is used to help calculate this at the end of the semester.
4. Python does not require a compiler! It is an interpreted language and is actually written in C. You should be able to access it immediately using your Terminal by typing 'python' or 'python3' although admittedly it is a bit early in the class for this.
Thank you so much for your details answer!
If in #4 you’re asking for a text editor for python (instead of a compiler), try Sublime Text or Atom.
Thxx
Hello, I’m quite confused on whether we have a discussion in ~6 minutes. When is our upcoming discussion, lab, and lecture time? Thank you!

You can check it on calendar if you go on cs10.org but in 6 minutes there’s a lecture where profs are going to be answering any questions students might have. I think there are three discussions throughout the day and again you can check the times available on the website.

Hello! Sorry for the confusion about timing! The website adjusts itself to your time zone and only shows the calendar from 9am to 9pm in your local time. To sum up:

- Lectures are Mon-Thurs at 9am PDT. The Thursday lecture is generally a Social Implications session.

- Labs also occur once every day Mon-Thurs, but vary in time: 10am-12pm Monday, 1pm-3pm Tuesday, 4pm-6pm Wednesday, and 7pm-9pm Thursday.

- Discussions occur twice a day on Tuesdays and Thursdays, from 10am-11am and 9pm-10pm. Pick one per day to attend - they can be at different times.

Keep in mind that all of these times are in PDT so if you're in a different time zone, you may not see all of them on the calendar on cs10.org if they don't fall between 9am and 9pm for your local time. Nevertheless, you are welcome to attend any of these sessions!

subject: Problem Sets
content:
Hello, I’m not sure if this was covered but... which problem sets are we supposed to do and by when? Are we only supposed to do the check offs for each problem set? What do we do with the webpage?

Thank you!

Hey!

You can find the list of problem sets and recommended (Early Bird) due dates here on the cs10 website: https://cs10.org/su20/labs.html - they're all formally due at the of the grading period they're assigned in (so Problem Sets 1-6 are due 7/05 by 11:59pm, but you can turn them in earlier!) 

You'll want to complete all the exercises in each Problem Set, the check-off questions just hit some of the bigger concepts and skills covered in that set, to make sure folks are learning what we're hoping they're learning by doing each set.

What webpage are you referring to? Can you link it in a followup?

Hey! This is the webpage I was talking about:

https://beautyjoy.github.io/bjc-r/topic/topic.html?topic=berkeley_bjc/intro_pair/2-loops-variables.topic

For every problem set, head to the webpage linked for that problem set and click the first link there. Read through the text and follow the instructions, clicking through using the ‘next’ button at the end of each page. There may be links to download starter code/blocks that you can drag/open/import into Snap. Highly recommend following all the instructions until you can’t click ‘next’ anymore. Once you feel comfortable with all of that problem set, head to the check off form and complete it by the deadline (early bird for extra points). You MUST fill out the check off form to get credit for each problem set. Remember there are a couple problem sets you can drop so don’t get too stressed about it, but if you try to stick to the early bird deadlines, you should be fine!
When will we know who we are doing the check-in (Friday) with? It's one of the questions on the pset 2's check off.
The TA you’ll have a check-in with corresponds to the time you signed up for in Project 0. There will be a Piazza post clarifying this soon.

subject: Lab
content:
You may wen over this before but I am still confused about the lab session.

Does it like an office hour where students can go there and ask questions?

Is there any attendance or assignment or extra credit opportunity during the lab session?

Thank you!

There are 2-3 problem sets released every week. These used to be called ‘labs’ which were generally completed during lab time. They have been relabeled and you can complete them in your own time, but working together with other students or by yourself during lab hours each day can be conducive to completing these on time, particularly if you encounter any issues or have any questions. It’s also a good space (along with discussion sections) to meet other students, especially for projects when you may be looking to work with a partner. However, your attendance in lab is not required - you can choose which labs you attend. Keep in mind that you don’t need to be working on the problem set from that day to attend the lab. There is no extra credit for attending, but make sure to complete the check off for each problem set to get credit for them!

subject: General Questions for Problem Set #2
content:
Hello! I had some general questions I wanted to confirm before turning in the build your own blocks check off. 

1) How do I know who I'm meeting with for Fridays? I know I am scheduled for 1:15 - 1:30. 

2) It says to only submit one snap file, but I have saved all the different steps as different snap files, so I have 8 different project files that cover problem set 2. I tried to put them into a folder and upload that, but that failed.

Furthermore, the variables and blocks do not match when I try to export a block into another project.

Should I rewrite all the code into one project file? How should I combine them into one file?

1. The TAs will be assigned once you turn in Project 0! Make sure you turn in Project 0 asap!

2. I am not sure so I don’t want to misinform you.
I'm not sure what the expectation is, but if you right-click on blocks you can duplicate them which might be helpful if you end up having to combine all your code.

Hi Paul, Aaron pointed out in another question that we are supposed to upload one single xml-file containing all the check-off-tasks that we did in Snap!.

However, can you explain why you would want to upload eight of your results? As far as I know there are only three check-offs you need to upload:
- the square-leaved flower
- the randomly walking sprite
- the field of flowers

In other words, you don‘t habe to submit the whole learning process you had in the program :)

Hey Uta

At first, I thought that we had to upload each snap file that we created in the process of going through the problem set. After clicking on the "Problem Set" tab on the cs10.0rg websight, I noticed that we only need to upload the specific codes they are asking for.

We generally advise you to create the different blocks required for each problem set in the same Snap! file, but it's often not possible if we give you several different starter files. When I took this class, I generally dealt with this by exporting the blocks from the starter files and importing them into the file I was working in. Seeing as you've completed the problem set, I would advise exporting the blocks from each of the required questions (the ones for the check-off), importing them into the same Snap file (and saving it), and making sure that you recreate an example for each of the problems/blocks you created before you save, export, and submit. For example, import your field of flowers block, drag it into the scripting area, fill the required blanks and check it runs correctly. A warning note about this: Snap can take a while and be glitchy at times so I suggest you make time to do this before the deadline just in case it crashes. In the future, I'd advise trying to complete the majority of the problem set in the same file.

subject: Problem with Conditionals and Reporters
content:
I was told if I post code, I should make it private. I'm not sure how to make a follow up message private, so I'm just posting this to instructors. 

When I type in the number 99, I get "C". I know I'm setting this problem up wrong, but I'm not sure how to do it.

Hi,

Posting to all instructors is fine.

When you write 90 > (number > 80) you’re not actually comparing two numbers. The parenthesized section “(number > 80)” evaluates to a boolean. Then you’re comparing 90 and some boolean, which doesn’t make sense. In math, “a < x < b” is really saying a < x AND x < b.

Secondly, I’ll mention a little optimization, which is optional but nevertheless a good way to write code. One number can only correspond to one letter grade. That is, if you get a 70 you cannot get a C and a B at the same time. Using this fact and what you know about the “if-else” block, how can you rewrite this block? (Hint: think about replacing stacked “if” blocks with nested “if-else”)

subject: Early Bird Deadlines Times
content: Is there a specific time we need to submit our problem sets by for early bird deadlines? Is it 11:59 PM PST on the day that's indicated for problem sets or is it 12:00 AM PST that day? Thank you!

11:59PM PDT ! (We are on Daylight Savings Time)

aka California time

aka GMT -07:00
When will be the general final deadline for each assignment ( for example like 24 hr after the early bird deadline?)

There are four grading periods for the class so the early bird deadlines keep you on track but as long as you submit by the deadline for that grading period, you’re fine (generally by 11:59pm PDT). Most things assigned in a two week period are due at these deadlines, unless specified otherwise.
First deadline: Sunday, 5 July
Second deadline: Friday, 17 July
Third deadline: Sunday, 2 August
Fourth deadline: Friday, 14 August
That being said, please don’t try to complete all the assignments the day before the deadline - it’s not possible to do all of them and do them well.

subject: [WEEK 2] PSET 4: Lists
content:
Please post questions related to the 'Lists' portion of this week's problem set below.

EARLY DEADLINE: July 1 @ 11:59PM PDT

Hello, I just finished going through Problem Set 4 and I didn't come across anything regarding creating a "Valid-Date Block", "sum of two smallest" block in the lesson, or answering "(Problem 3) Sum of numbers between x and y." I wanted to ask if I potentially missed something, a mistake was made, or it's covered somewhere else? Thanks!
Hi Jeffrey, please refresh the form. The questions have just been updated. Sorry about that!
I was wondering the same thing.

I'm doing the keep function right now. When I assigned a list of items to a variable and use the variable in the keep function, it kept returning "error expecting list but getting number." Once I took the list out and put it straight into the keep function though, it worked. Just now, I returned the list back to the "set variable to" block, and it worked again. I also tried taking out the list and placing it in the script workplace (but not in either the set variable block or the keep function), and I kept the variable in the keep function, and it worked as well. Is this just Snap being wonky? And is there any way I can prevent it from happening in the future because I spent a good twenty minutes finagling around thinking I did something wrong...

Snap! does this funny thing where any created variables are originally assigned to the value 0. 

If you had a global variable and you used the "set" block to assign it to a list, you want to remember to actually run the block so it sets the variable to the list.

Based on the behavior you've described (taking the list out and putting it in the script workplace), you seem to be using a global variable. The reason why it still works here is because you've previously assigned the variable to the list, but dragging the list out of the 'set' block does not automatically reassign it to 0.

If this is not the case, perhaps make a private post with your code, and we'd be happy to figure out what's going on

Hi, I am working on my acronym block but continue to get an error that says expecting list but getting text and am unsure on how to fix this, or even what this means. Any insight on this would be appreciated, as well as a hint to push me in the right direction
I fixed the problem I was getting with the error but for some reason now when I click on the script nothing happens. Instead of the block reporting an acronym, it doesn't report anything

Highly recommend using the visible stepping tool to see where the block gets stuck. Without seeing your code, I’m not sure what the exact problem is but I’ll suggest steps towards fixing it: test your code bit by bit. If you have a bunch of HOFs and other blocks that are forming one large block, take out each part of it and make sure that each part works correctly one by one. If you’re dealing with loops, try putting a say block inside the loop so you can see what changes with each iteration. Hopefully this helps you problem solve the code yourself. Otherwise, feel free to make a private post with your code.

I have also received an error saying that the acronym block is expecting a list but getting text. I have tried using the visible stepping tool, but it doesn't go into my block to show the steps. It just immediately says the error. Is there anything else that I can try to help solve this problem?

For visible stepping to go into your block definition, you need to close the definition, enable visible stepping, then reopen it.

Also, when it says "expecting a list but getting text", it means that a certain input is looking specifically for a list, but you are passing in text instead.

I have been trying to figure out this one for a while now. Can anyone help me? Write an expression that selects from a list of words the ones that start with a vowel. (Hint: Use contains in the Variables palette.)

There are a couple of different steps here. First, how do we distinguish vowels from other letters? Hint: think of how you might distinguish letters from numbers or other characters in Snap. 
Next, let’s group the vowels together. How would you take the 5 vowels and store them in a way that you can access them later?
Finally, take a look at HOFs that could help you. Hint: look at the domain and range (input and output) of each of the HOFs to see which one acts selectively the way you need it to.
Got it, thank you!

I am working on building the expand block but I am stuck. I know how to figure out what the number in the sentence is but I am not sure how to move forward since I don't know where the number is in the list. Can anyone help or provide any hints?

With the understanding that numbers could be anywhere in the sentence, think about how you would look through each position in the sentence. If it helps, think about how you would do this for a different data type. 
Next, once you know how to find where in the sentence the number(s) is/are, how can you access that position to obtain the number and then the position after that to obtain the word.
Hi, I am also working on the expand block. Can someone please give a hint on how to access the position in a list? Is there a reporter we have to import from another library maybe?

The blocks used when dealing with a list are generally under the ‘variables’ tab. Also, take another look through the first few pages of problem set 4 - some basics about working with lists are there.
Thanks for your reply. But I don‘t want to tell the script „access position 3“. Instead, I want the script to find the number and then tell me at which position the number is.
I have been trying to do the expand block for 4 hours. Can anyone give me a hint on which blocks to use? I'm really having a hard time.

@Uta, let’s break it down into different steps. To find a number in the script, you’ll have to look through each word in the sentence. How would you do this? Say the sentence is 5 words/items long. How do you get the script to look through the items exactly 5 times, while keeping track of which iteration it’s on? Is there a loop that could help here?
Thanks for your help Samhita, is there a way you could explain how to insert a the repeated word after you find a way to isolate the number and remove it from the sentence?

Once you find the position of the word, you can use that to find the position of the repeated word because it’s in the next position. The position you want to insert words into would likely be similar to this as well. A tricky thing with this block sometimes is the order of operations - make sure you don’t remove the number before you have saved it somewhere/used it to insert the repeated word the correct number of times. If you’re having trouble inserting the word, take another look under the variables tab in Snap and see if there’s anything that can help you.
I figured it out. Thank you so much!!
Me too thank you very much!
I am stuck on the longest word block. Can someone please help and explain how to better understand lists and the way they function in order to find the longest word in a sentence!

I’d take a look at my slides about HOFs from lecture. Specifically, check out the slides talking about finding the largest number in a list. Try to extend this idea into how we can figure out the longest word. The gist is to have a helper that returns the longer of two words!
Is there a way we can compare 2 lists of individual characters? It's for the Hangman part of PS4.
There is a way of finding out if something appears in a list, you can find that in "Variables". And in addition, there is a way to change the item that you search for every round. Does that help you?
how do we find if there is already something that appears in a list?

How do I find if there is a number in my list? What I put for my expand block is that I used "sentence" as the user's input for my block. Then I used the for each item loop and I put: "for each item in sentence" "if (list --> sentence (sentence)) contains "numbers" (which I defined as a variable and used the "numbers 1 to 10 block") then report true. And then when I input a sentence with a number it says that it expects list but is getting text. Can someone please help me out here?
I think the "for each item loop" block requires a list as an input, you can try to split the sentence into a list first using the given reporter block under Operator)?
See if there is also a block that will help you see if any given item is a number (regardless of what number it is)

I am working on the expand block and I am having trouble selecting the number (once I make the sentence into a list) and making the word that follows repeat however many times is specified. I have been working on this for a couple hours and I am still not getting anywhere. Are there any hints that I can have to point me in the correct direction?

subject: [WEEK 2] PSET 5: Algorithms
content:
Please post questions related to the 'Algorithms' portion of this week's problem set below.

EARLY DEADLINE: July 3 @ 11:59PM PDT

Hi! I'm having trouble understanding the memoization block (find the number X in the sorted list X using X). Could someone help explain what I'm supposed to do, and maybe give a hint to nudge me in the right direction? Thanks!

The version of the block including memorization is fairly similar to the block without (find num X in sorted list X) except it checks the second/memory list first to see if the number you’re looking for has already been found before. The second/memory list’s index numbers will include the values in the sorted list, and the values corresponding to these indexes will be the positions from the sorted list. An example: if you have a sorted list [1,4,7,8], your memory list will be 8 items long. At index 4 of the memory list, you will have 2 (i.e. the position of 4 in the sorted list). At index 7 of the memory list, you will have 3, and so on. The number entered in the memory list corresponds to the position in the sorted list. This way, if you’ve found 4 in the sorted list before, you can simply look up item 4 of the memory list and find its position in the sorted list. Hopefully this helps understand how memoization is incorporated in this block. If you have questions about your code once you’ve attempted it following the instructions in the problem set, feel free to create a private post.
Thank you so much! That definitely helps!

I'm a bit confused about the other blocks in the script that was provided to us... Do we have to code the helper block "find the number in the sorted list X" algorithm (the one with the "memory" input)? And what are the "max random" and "test runs" variables for? I'm also not sure what the "time..." blocks are for...

I have also just started with that pset. I am sorry I can not answer the first question since I am not there yet, but regarding the variables: What might help you is to take a look inside the  time block to understand what the variables you mentioned do. The time block as such is used to measure the time it takes for your script to be computed, in this case your block. I only know that by coincidence because I think it was mentioned in a lecture.

Oh, I was wondering, in pset 4 we are supposed to code three helper blocks in total, just in case that was your question. The one with the memory input should be the last one to be coded. Maybe the instructor's answer above in @54_f1 can help you further.
Sorry pset5 of course

Thanks for your reply! Cool, so the three blocks we're coding are the ones for finding a number in an unsorted list, in a sorted list, and in a sorted list (with "memory" as an input). Your reply helped me figure out what the "time" blocks do, but I'm still not sure what we need to do with them... I didn't see anything in the instructions of checkoff form about how we should be using these blocks (unless I missed something).

The purpose of the timing is to give you a way to quantify how fast each script runs. There is one in each sprite. You do not have to edit anything in them. All you need to do is fill out the definition of the 3 number finding blocks, and then running the timer procedures.

Regarding the max random and test runs variables, they allow you to alter the size of your input list and the number of timed trials you run. The larger the input list, the more time it should take.

The timing gives you an opportunity to see the difference in run time between the unsorted, sorted, and sorted memoized functions. It is an emphasis for how the same purpose can be achieved in different ways at different levels of efficiency.
Got it, thank you so much!

Sorry, another question here. I think that I've successfully made the memoize block (Find number X in the sorted list X using X) as it does what it's supposed to do, but when I use the timer it actually takes longer than the other methods? Should I make a private post to ask about this? Additionally, is this block part of the checkoff? It's not listed but I just want to make sure.
Make sure that you are not re-creating the memoized list every time you run the function! You want to make sure that a value gets memoized the first time it is called

Hi, I got stuck in problem set 5 with the sorted list. A moment ago I thought I had figured it all out, the algorithm was working fine until I checked the very last number in a list and then something collided. That showed me the code is not working the way it should. I also feel like I did what I learned is called "hard-coding" since I am not using HOFs... I did not come up with any idea on how to use them in this case...

So, I think my main question is: Do I need a HOF? Which HOF is suited for this task?

The diagram on the problem set that demonstrates how sorted list works is quite useful. Another way to think about it is, say I have chose a number between 0-100 and your job is to guess what it is in the fewest number of guesses. After every guess, I will tell you if my number is higher or lower than yours. Naturally, you would begin with 50 so that you can immediately eliminate half of the numbers based on my feedback.

Now I ask you to consider: Are you mapping a function to every item of the list, filtering based on a specific condition, or combining item together? (or any combination of those actions?)

Thanks for the hint!

I believe mapping every item is not what I want here since the purpose of my function is explicitely  to not have to look at all the items.

I tried filtering half of the numbers, but especially if I filtered out the lower half I lost the position of my number in the original list, that is, in the new, shorter list it is going to have another position, of course.

I do have an idea for combine, I recall building a little function that finds the maximum number out of two and then using combine with that function.

Am I on the right track?
Hi, I also tried to reduce the list based on the conditions but I am having trouble figuring out the position as the list updates. Can anyone provide some hints?

Uta, 

You are on kind of the right track, but consider that even though we may be "filtering" in some sense here, the complexity of the problem may not best fit a HOF. Remember that HOFs can be written as a loop, and sometimes one way may be easier than the other.

Seems like map and keep are not working as smoothly as we'd hope. The function that operates similarly to the maximum number out of two may help you find the number, but it may not work in the way that the diagram hints to us. Perhaps we may be able to make use of some variables and/or some type of loop?

QiWen,

Great on identifying that you need to keep track of the position. The diagram on the pset about this problem is also clueing you in that you may also want to keep track of min and max variables. How do they change with every time you "cut down" the problem? 

Also, another way to consider the diagram: notice how it does not actually throw away the 1/2 of the list it doesn't want. It is simply focusing on the half it cares about. Why is this important for the goal of this block(being able to report the position of a given number)?

Is there an instructor to whom I can send a copy of my code to for the "find the number in the sorted list" block? When I tested it manually with every combination I can think of it works, but the "time sorted number finder" is still saying that my finder block is not working properly. I've gone through many rounds of debugging now and I'm really not sure what I'm doing wrong at this point. Thanks!
Okay, I did some further testing and found the issue. Is there a way to delete my post?

Hi! So I made the memoization block and it's working. However, when I run the timer block, the times I get are around the same time as the time it takes for the sorted list block. The average seems to be a bit lower than the sorted list block though. Is the memoization block supposed to be significantly faster than the sorted list block or only a little bit? Thanks!

Hi Heather,

Make sure that you are not re-creating the memoized list every time you run the function! You want to make sure that a value gets memoized the first time it is called. If this is not the case, perhaps you might want to run it on number lists of larger size to see a bigger difference.

subject: Details of Project one.
content:
Hello,

Contain only letters within ROYGBV' :

I'm guessing this means I should include this instruction in the code?

In the code below b is a global variable set to list. I'm trying to add one until the statement is true, in order to count the guesses. However, no matter how many times I guess it, it keeps showing the length as 1. I'm not sure where is my mistake . Thanks in advance!

Howdy doody!

It seems like there are two questions: Should I be including instructions on only have ROYGBV, and why the length of your variable b keeps staying as 1. I'll address these one by one

Should I include instructions?
Yes! However, instead of simply stating this as part of the game's instructions, you should also check for this within your game code to make sure that a guess is valid before it gets logged. There could very well be a user that sees the instruction but ignores it which could present some issues.

Why does my length stay at 1?
Note the "set b" block. How often does it get called when you run your game? What effect will this have on the data stored in b? Once you know and understand the answers to these two questions, what needs to happen with this set block?  Where should it go?

If you have any further questions feel free to follow up below!

Gotcha! Thank you! Now I stuck on another problem, even if the player figures out the word, it continues asking what's your guess. It doesn't stop. But on my repeat statement I'm checking it, so it should run until its false. But it keeps running no matter if the player guessed the word or not.
Be careful with the spacing between the numbers. If your matching slots block reports "1234", you would not want to compare that against "1 2 3 4", as they are not the same.

Also, I'm not sure how to check all the letters in a word if they consist of ROYJBV. Should I use if statement for every letter in a word ? But then how to make sure if a letter is only in the range of ROYJBV. I'm kinda lost on my own thoughts.
See below answer!
Thanks!
Also, if the word is longer than 4 or a letter is not in the range, what should it do? Repeat or just send the message about the wrong input.

In the spec for part 1, it says:

Assume the user always types a four-letter code made up of these letters: ROYGBV. That is, we don’t ask that you do any error checking.

In other words, you can always assume that the code the user enters contains only ROYGBV letters and is exactly 4 letters long
Is that ok if I'll show the player the length and guessed word on the stage, so that way the player can see the word and the correct slots.

That's fine. I would actually rethink how you store the number of guesses (I'm assuming that's what you mean by length). How could you do this with just a number? It'll be more clear for the user and more in line with the expectations of the first project.

The number of guesses shows the correct answer. I'm using the length of the list every time when the player makes a guess and it adds a number to the list. In the end, I just use the length. Isn't it correct? It gives me the right number of guessses.

When it adds a number to the list for each guess, what does this number represent? If the number added each time is '1' to signify a single guess, consider how you could do this without the use of lists. Otherwise, you have the correct idea!

subject: Catch-All Deadline
content: If we are not able to finish any assignment/project by the early bird deadline for the first two weeks, do we submit them by the catch-all deadline, and is the first one July 5th? Is there a place where we can check what all four of the catch-all deadlines are? Thanks!

Yes, this is correct. You aren't penalized for not being able to hit any of the early bird deadlines, but you must have the two week's worth of assignments in by the catch-all deadline.

The catch-all deadlines are every 2 weeks. This means you have until that day at 11:59PM PDT

The first deadline is Sun July 5.

The next one is Fri July 17.

Then Sun Aug 2.

The final deadline is Friday August 14th, the last day of class.

subject: Sprites in Project 1
content:
Hello,

I had a question about using sprites in Project 1. I assigned one sprite to act as the computer/player 1 and another sprite to act as player 2. This results in the user having to switch between the two sprites when trying to submit and check new guesses. I added comments to guide the user and indicate how to switch between the two sprites. (I've attached my code for reference.) However, I'm not sure if this is what the instructors had in mind while assigning us this project... Is switching between the two sprites acceptable? 

Thank you,

Irene Yang

Proj1_IreneYang.xml

Hey Irene!

Just took a look over your project and I think while having two sprites is fine, the flow of the game shouldn't require the user to switch between the two sprites in order to progress. Right now you have blocks and comments that describe the order of the game —these blocks should be connected together so that when I as the user start the game,  it just runs on its own.

Another way to think about this is to pretend that the user cannot access your code. Instead the only thing I have access to is the flag on the top right-hand and anything I can see on the stage.

subject: Questions about project 1
content:
Hi

I have three questions before I submit my project:

1) (pic 1) My matching slots block kept spitting outputs like 1004 instead of 14 when reporting which characters were correct. The only way I could figure out how to get rid of the zeros was adding else to the if and then saying set (variable) to blank space.  Is this okay? Or is this a faster way to do this? 

2) (pic 2) I was able to give player two the option to keep guessing after guessing incorrect through the forever command but even after they guess the code right, after 5 seconds it asks to guess again; how do I get rid of this? I tried using the repeat until answer = correct code in place of forever but that didn't work. 

3) Do I need an ending statement such as "thanks for playing?"

.

Thanks for all your help :)

1. There likely are other ways to accomplish this, but as long as this accomplishes what is necessary from the spec, this should be fine. One thing to think about would be repetition - if you find yourself copying and pasting the same thing with only a few changes, there are often ways to abstract the process.
2. The forever block runs, as the name suggests, forever, so you’d have to include something within the loop to stop the loop at the correct point. The repeat until block is also a valid option but make sure you’re thinking about what you want inside that loop and what should go outside that loop. 
3. The ending note isn’t strictly necessary (there aren’t extra points for it), but if you would like to include it, you’re very welcome to. 
Make sure to read through the spec one last time before submitting to make sure everything is according to the instructions!

subject: PSET4 "Expand _" Block
content:
Hi, 

I have been working on the "expand_" block all day long, and I haven't figured out how to do it. At this point I don't know how or what to do to make it work, so I was wondering if someone is still up to help me.

This is the file: ps4.xml

I am sorry I bring this up until now.

Hi Daniela!

Before you begin code, I strongly recommend you write out your approach using pseudocode (a combination of code and English), like such:

For example, say I was trying to figure out the acronym block. The steps I might follow are:

  1. Keep only the words in a list that have capital letters
  2. Convert the words from step 1 to their first letter
  3. Combine everything back together

The idea here is to have a step by step plan so you don't get lost in your code. How would you do this for expand?

Other things to consider:

  • How will HOFs help you? Will they help you at all? Are you doing any mapping, keeping, or combining?
  • Consider the difference between for i and for item and when one is used over the other. If you have any questions, there is a helpful guide under the Snap! Resources section under the Resources tab on cs10.org
  • One other strategy is to talk through the problem out loud (we call this "rubber ducking")

Also, what was your method of approach for this problem?

I'm trying to approach this problem by doing the following steps: 

-keep only the number in the list and word after number

-make the word repeat for n times

-combine word repeated n times with everything

This is a great start to pseudocode. Now let's consider the best way to convert this to Snap! blocks.

You seem to have the hang of filtering out the number, but how would you also filter out the word after that? Is the keep HOF the best method here, or can we use a for-loop?

(hint: I'm going to point you to the guide that I mentioned. You can find it at https://cs10.org/su20/resources-snap.html let me know if I can clarify anything in it for you)
Maybe using the for-loop.
Yes, you can certainly try that. You may have figured it out during lab but if not, let me know if any questions arise.

subject: Don't know how to generate secret code
content: Hello. I'm so stuck. I went to office hours and I've been working on this problem for a long time. I don't know what I'm doing wrong. Any direction would be so helpful.

Hey there!

I think I'm getting the gist of what you're trying to accomplish here —just that some steps seem to be a bit mixed up. I'll try my best to break this down into parts you can follow.

Getting the random letters
It looks like you already have the right idea of getting one random letter from the list of letters. The next step you should take is to store that letter somewhere, like a list for example! Once you figure out how to do this for one letter, you'll simply need to repeat this process n times to get the letters for a code of the desired length.

Letters -> Code

Another good idea you have currently is using combine to join the letters, although it's important to remember that combine takes in a list as an input, whereas item _ will return a letter (or something else) for this block. An alternative idea would be to use the list of random letters you generated in the previous step, and combining them together similar to how you're doing it now. It's important to note that generally you don't want to be using a HOF within a loop, as HOFs like map, keep, and combine, were really meant to simplify what would otherwise be a rather verbose for loop involving a list operation. So in the case of generate code, you might consider having it towards the end when you've finished choosing your letters, and you're trying to go from a list of letters -> a word/code.

Hey Emersyn,

Thanks for stopping by OH and for being determined about solving this problem.

I hope Maxson's explanation clarifies some questions you had. Do let us know if any other ones come up!

subject: I am having a lot of trouble with the "find number in sorted list" algorithm.  Can anyone help?
content:
Hello,

I have spent a significant amount of time on this, and I still am unable to figure it out.  Can anyone help me?

Quick note: The algorithm you’re trying to implement is called Binary Search and it involves an elegant and complex concept, so it’s natural to have trouble with this (I did).

Quick note about terminology: number vs index. 

Consider the list [2, 4,6,7].

The *number* 2 is at the first *index*. The indices impose order on a list. The number 2 comes before 6 because the index of 2 = 1 while the index of 6 = 3. The index is always ordered: 1,2,3,4,... 

Now when you look for a number in an unsorted list, every *index* has the potential to be the location of the number you want, so you have to laboriously look through all of them.

When the list is sorted, however, you can compare your number to some specific *number* at the *middle index* (if there are an even number of items then choose your pick for a tiebreaker). Then if your number is greater than it, you know for a fact that it can’t be any where in the front half (convince yourself of this before moving on). Vice versa if your number is less.

Now once you have chopped off half of the list, treat it as a new list and keep chopping it down until you have a single number. (This is guaranteed to work because dividing something by 2 eventually gets to 1. Rounding is basically carried out by tie-breaking). That final number is your number.

In code, try to have 2 variables representing the first index and the last index, basically 1 and the length of the list itself, respectively. Surely the first one has to be less than the second one. To find the middle index, add the two variables previously defined then divide by 2. If your number is greater than the number at that middle index, shift the lower index to the middle number. If your number is less than the number at the middle index, shift the bigger index to the middle number. Rinse and repeat until you get to one single number, at which point report it.
Ok, thank you so much!  I think I was just having a bit of trouble with the syntax of snap and I kept mixing around whether I wanted the actual value or the index in my functions.

subject: Does anyone know how to index a list on snap?
content:
Hi, 

I'm just wondering if anyone knows if there's a simple way to index a list in Snap because it seems that whenever I have an issue or get stuck, it's because I don't know how to find the position of an item on a list and have to manually count or do something else.

I’m assuming by “index a list” you mean find the index of any arbitrary element in a list.

There’s no quick way in general to do that but luckily you can just loop over the list in order until you find the desired item and return the index. If the list is sorted you can do binary search which should be faster.

If you download list utilities from the library (go to the page icon, choose libraries, then choose list utilities), there are a number of list blocks that track the index of the input item in functions. Otherwise, I have just been tracking the index manually with variables like you said. Hope this helps!

subject: PSET6
content: I don't really understand what the output should be. Also what we need to do with the test block? Do we need to create two test blocks, one for merge column and another one for merge up ?

If you haven't had a chance to play around with 2048 yet, I would highly suggest you check out the game to get a feel for its mechanics! https://play2048.co/

The arrow key movements correspond to merging in various directions. In other words, pressing the up arrow key corresponds to merging up.

For a more technical explanation of how merging works, check out this blog post: https://steven.codes/blog/cs10/2048-merge/ (also will be linked in the spec)

A 4x4 board with the given values comes out to look like this

4008
2000
20320
40016

Considering the rules of merging (described in detail in the blog post), if we merge up this board, what do we expect the resulting board to look like? (hint: merging up column 1 will result in a new column with values 4, 4, 4, 0 from top to bottom)

Based on those expected values, you can then input that into the "expecting output" portion of the test block.

We haven't written "merge up" yet, so your test will automatically report False. But the goal of writing the test first is to figure out, assuming the block works, what we expect the output to be. Thus, when we actually write the block, the test helps to ensure that our block is working properly.

subject: Problemset 7
content:
Q1: how should I use the green [ ]=bug block?

Q2: what does it mean by have the player say I hit object (does the change pen color "remind" the player or do I need to display it on the stage?

Q3: how do I reset the timer? What is the flag? Is it the sprite?

 

Q4: Am I do it right? Can the sprite goes to negative position?

Hey Ailin!

I'll try to address these questions one by one.

Q1: Think about where we would find a "bug", or more specifically where it's being stored. One of the key ideas in this portion is that our game board will store all of the game's information for what's at each tile. So another way to think about this is, how do I know I'm on a tile with a bug? A hint is that you're going to be using one of the blocks that's already in Finish Move.

Q2: This part is referring to when your player (the sprite you control) hits a bug while playing the game. So if you were playing, pressed right, and landed on a bug, then it should change the color of the sprite, and say the dialogue. Part of it is already implemented for you in the block actually, so I'd focus on how you can get the player so say "Oops, I hit a bug!". This is related to Q1 so once you figure out how to check that you're on a bug tile, you should also be able to fill in this dialogue.

Q3. There is a reset timer block in "Sensing"; the green flag can be found on the top right corner of Snap! it's purpose is to "start" a program, kind of like an "on" button so to speak.

Q4: I think this solution has the right idea, but I would think about how to generalize this so that it works regardless of what position you are on the map. Note that you shouldn't head into "negative" space or anywhere beyond the bounds of your board (so positive values larger than the dimensions of the board are not valid either). Think about how you can get the position of the sprite and make changes to its position based on the button that was clicked, its current location, and whether or not the actual movement itself is valid.

subject: Midterm Logistics
content:
Hello Everyone!

As you know we will be having our midterm this weekend, so we have the logistics for you in advance to help prepare. Please read this post all the way through to get all the information.

  1. We will release a two-part, untimed, take-home midterm exam online using bCourses on Saturday 7/18 @ 12:01am PDT. The two parts are (a) with Snap!  – a coding challenge and (b) without Snap!– the traditional “paper” exam, but delivered online.
  2. You will have 72 hours to complete it; it will be due Monday 7/20 @ 11:59pm PDT. You may take as little or as much time as you need. However, we do not anticipate this exam to take 72 hours. Expect to set aside ~4 hours to take this exam: 1 hours for the “in-lab” final (part a), and 3 hours for the “paper” final (part b). 
  3. You are to complete the final exam alone without consulting any other student or online resources except for Snap! & Python in part (a), and we will ask everyone to sign an attestation that they have upheld that policy when they submit their exam.
  4. You will be able to ask any clarifying questions by making a private post to a Piazza thread we will open up when we release the final. Our staff will respond and answer your questions as quickly as we can, and post the results back to you on Piazza and to a “clarifications” page on the online exam itself (so others will see them and not need to ask the same question).

We will make another post once the exam is released announcing its beginning and linking the clarification doc. Monday 7/20 classes will focus on new material and not be covering anything on the exam, please continue to use piazza for clarifications during that time. In the meantime, some things to keep in mind:

  • The website resources page is a phenomenal study tool
  • We have a "clobber" policy, so that if you don't do as well as you liked you can replace your midterm score with your final exam score if you do better
  • We will be maintaining standards of academic integrity, so please follow the guidelines

CLARIFICATIONS:

  • You will be allowed to use all handwritten notes you have taken
  • Testable material includes all of the lectures (2-11) and problem sets (1-9)
    • This includes the guest lectures
    • Social Implications readings/sessions will not be tested
    • Discussions technically will be tested too, but they clarify material introduced in lectures and problem sets

You've been preparing for this all along,

Aaron
For the coding part of the test, I noticed how Fall and Spring exams test us on making Fractals while it’s completely a diff topic for Summer. What should we expect for our midterm?
Fractals!

subject: Fall2019 mt
content:
Could you explain these two questions, please?

Thank you!

Question 5 is about concurrency and parallel computing. The idea is that max speedup is limited by the serial (so non-parallel) portion of the program. If there are infinitely many cores, the serial portion of the code has a significant impact on the program's performance, hence the equation in the answer. That formula is called Amdahl's Law; you should definitely look it up if you are interested! But I think concurrency might be out of scope for your midterm?

Question 6 is about converting hexadecimal (base 16) and binary numbers into what we are used to working with -- base 10 numbers -- and then performing operations on them. Refer to discussion worksheet 1 from week 1 if you are not sure how to perform this conversion. 

Hopefully that was helpful. Please follow up if you are still confused about question 6!

subject: Python text editors
content: Hi! I'm looking through pset 10 and was wondering whether I should download Sublime Text or Atom. Is one preferred over the other? Good question!

Personally I used Sublime Text 3 all throughout college but I recently switched over to VSCode. Generally speaking, it doesn't really matter which one you pick at the end of the day, the biggest thing that motivated my switch was the ability to customize the appearance of the editor (aesthetics are super important). 

VSCode (and Atom?) both come with a built-in way to run Python as well as a debugger which can be particularly useful. Sublime Text 3 in my experience is a lot more responsive however, and it really depends on your workflow that you develop.

But otherwise it's really aesthetics imo
If you want to feel like some of the very first software engineers, you can also use VIM. However, I don't recommend this (it's still a cool side topic though!).

Hi, Eden,

I just want to clarify this. 

"You MUST properly denote and cite any direct quotations used in your assignment. To be clear: any time you copy any lines of text from any of your sources, you must (1) place the copied text in quotation marks and (2) include the author’s name in parenthesis after the quote."

If my information is from the website, do I still need to quote the author even if I paraphrased it into my own words and didn't copy off the author's words?

As far as I know from writing many essays, anytime you reference another's work, even if it is in your own writing, you have to cite it.  You still took info from that work and read that person's argument, even in your own words it is another's ideas, therefore, you need to cite where it came from.  Paraphrasing is still a form of quoting a person's work.  Its always better to be safe rather than sorry so I would say you are always better off citing since it is very easy to accidentally plagiarize.

Yeah true but they also said something around the lines of not giving us full points if our whole essay is based of cited quotes. Not neccessarily since I imagine some of your sentences have to be your own analysis in some form, as an example I might write (this is completely made up:

Mark Jacobs argues in his paper The Dangers of AI that...

(in this situation I am directly referencing his argument regardless of if I put it into my own words, so that's why I cited it rather than not giving credit). 

It is possible in the future AI could be used to harm humanity if used incorrectly.  For example, AI might become advanced enough to one day...

(this is my own interpretation, I use info I can understand and garner from the articles I have read and am making my own analysis so unless I give an example that I got from a source specifically like a specific story or case I probably don't need to cite anything since its my own ideas.

Sorry if this was confusing, all of this is from a history major not someone who works in STEM so citing might be different in a more technical work

Any time the words are taken directly from the source, you should put quotes around them so that you are not plagiarizing. Other than that, the post is short enough that the citations at the end will suffice for crediting the authors with ideas. 

However, the paper is more than just re-wording descriptions from your cited authors. We expect you to clearly and effectively summarize their information and apply it to the conversation of your paper. In other words, you are using the info from the sources to talk about the technology and its implications at a broader level.

That would be a big part of the project, but the post does require that you also cover the tech at a high level.

Would it be ok to write about an innovation that has been researched and developed but is not yet widely in use? For the implications section, I would focus on potential consequences rather than ones that have already been observed. I just wanted to check since the spec says to think of an innovation that has changed the world. Thanks!

subject: Why you can't use [::-1] in pset 10, and what it actually means
content:
I don't know how to do my cs70 hw so i decided to make a post about why you are not allowed to use [::-1] in pset 10 since there seems to be some confusion around list notation in lab.

In Python, you select specific item(s) from a list with [:::]. Why do you have three sets of colons? Well, the expression can be interpreted like this:
[ index of the first item you want to take(inclusive) : index of the last item you want to take(not inclusive) : slicing(the difference between the index of each item that you take; default == 1) ]
*remember that python uses 0-indexing, so the index of the first item will always be 0.*
for example:
a = [2, 12, 53, 90, 20, 17]
a[2] = 12
a[1:3] = [12, 53]
a[::2] = [2, 53, 20]
Therefore, [::-1] is basically saying: take all the items in a list and join them reversely such that item that was originally at index -1 of the list will be the first item, and the item at -2 will be the second item, etc. It is a super fast way of doing 'reverse_string', but it is considered "cheating" for the purpose of this lab.
hopefully this is helpful and please follow up if you have any questions :)

subject: Curious About Encryption and Hacking
content:
For part of the final project, I was thinking about making some kind of random password generator, with some kind of user interface that you can specify certain things about the password, and also keeping storage of all your accounts and passwords. While I was creating the random password block, I couldn't help but wonder how easy is this to reverse engineer and decrypt how these passwords are generated. I tried to put a lot of randomnesses, but im wondering if there is any way to know if these passwords are actually somewhat secure? 

Here are some example outputs, with a specified length of 11, and must include # and &

This is cool! Youre not really encrypting any secret message but rather generating a random sequence of characters given some constraints. Because of that, there's not really much to decrypt, but if you are asking about the strength of the passwords it generates (which refers to how easy it would be to guess the password), then this looks solid! One suggestion is that you pick only one letter to use a bunch of times. Try using random.choice(ascii_letters) to get a certain number of different letters.

subject: Problem Set 11, Exercise 4
content: I'm still having the same problem with exercise 4. The same code runs fine in Spyder. I also asked a friend to run the same code through his terminal, and it worked as well. I don't think I'm running a duplicate out-of-date file, and I'm relatively certain terminal is running the most up-to-date current file. I've attached a picture of the code in Sublime, a picture of the terminal error, and a picture of the same code working in Spyder.

Hi Ailun!

There seem to be two different errors here —they're not related to each other though so that's good.

IndentationError
The simpler of the two errors to fix has to do with indentations vs. spaces. If you highlight all of the text in sublime text, you'll notice some dots where there are spaces, and longer lines where there are tabs. Sublime Text has a useful feature where you can turn all the indentations into tabs by going to View>Indentations>Convert Indentation to Tabs.

TypeError
This one is not quite so clear. There aren't any apparent syntax or logical errors I see in your substitute_base function. My question is whether or not you redefine "helper" later on in your code for another function. Python will go with the last definition of a particular function, so naming multiple "helper" functions identically will cause erroneous behavior. Otherwise could you provide an email with your code?
The indentation error was for a different, older piece of code that I deleted, but I did indeed redefine the helper function later on. I changed it, and it works now. Thank you so much!

subject: Detail Removal in Python
content:
Something thats nice about snap is that you can make blocks inside of other blocks, and when a function is definied, the definiiton is stored somehwere not on the main screen. 

Then once all the details are broken down into a couple general blocks, our main snap code an be a nice simple 4 or 5 blocks. 

However, in python are we able to hide anything from the main page? or does everything have to be front and center? Like in python can we make a function, and then just have the definition of that function stored away in a side bar like snap, and then we just type it out whenever we need it? Or does the definiton of every function we use have to allways be displayed at all times?

Depending on which text editor you use, you can click an arrow to tye left of def function_name(): so that it hide whatever is underneath it. This is more of a feature of what text editor you use rather than a feature of python though.

In addition to the student's response above. Sometimes it can also be worthwhile to define different python files that hold different logic, and importing them where necessary. That way, instead of having all of your logic on one file, you can distribute them across multiple to make things more readable overall, as well as functions easier to locate depending on how your files are organized.

subject: Stuck on specific problem in project
content:
We are using a python module called Tkinter in order to make a user interface for our random password generator. Although the Tkinter is outside of the scope of what we are taught in this class, I feel like the problem we have could be solved. 

This function above is triggered when a button is pressed, and it displays the label on the UI in a specific grid position. The highlited line, is the line that sets a global variable to what is entered in to the text box which is called e.get(). And the line bellow that one is the command saying where to display the text on the screen. myLabel1 is a global variable, so every time we display a new Label, our global variable is changed. To delete the variable we use the mylabel.destroy() or myLabel.forget() and that deletes only the current text that is equated with the global variable for mylabel. 

The problem is, when there is more than one label, the program forgets the old versions of mylabel so when I go to delete the mylabel, it only deletes the most current one, which is what I show in the two videos below: 

IMG_3686.mov

IMG_3687.mov

The main goal is to just be able to clear all the entries whenever we hit hide lists.

This function above is how we display the lists on the screen. LIST_OF_ACCOUNTS is a global list that has each item as the account info. 

This is an example of

LIST_OF_ACCOUNTS[i] =

First the item above is set to the label, then the label is displayed on the screen, this repeats for the length of the list. But because the label is global it only know the last version, therefore only deleting the last item. 

It seems like using a global variable does not work because I can only delete a specific item using the destroy and forget calls. 

Sorry for the long message, I just thought more details would be helpful

Thank you!

- Paul

Not familiar with TKinter, but after some Googling, it seems like you may want to try hiding the grid with grid_forget() instead of forgetting myLabel1 (since, as you said, myLabel1 only keeps track of the most recent entry?)

subject: Question about word --> list block
content:
Hi, 

I'm trying to make the word --> list block which takes in a word and reports a list of all of the characters in that word. I used a for loop to iterate through all the letters of the word and return the letter according to which number it is at, but I keep getting an error that says "expecting number but getting text." 

Screen_Shot_2020-08-04_at_3.35.09_PM.png

You've got the correct general idea, but let's see what's going on within the code:

Say I have the word "recursion" that I'm trying to convert to a list. 

The first letter is r and the last letter is n. The for loop within your code would then be "for i from r to n"

What does it mean to go from r to n? This doesn't make sense, because we can't concretely define going from one letter to another like we can with going from, say, 1 to 10. 

This, plus the error you're getting, indicates to us that the for loop needs to go from one number to another, such as from 1-10. If we are trying to go from the first to the last letter of the input word, what might the actual bounds of the for loop need to be?

Thank you! I changed the bounds to for 1 to length of word, but I'm still getting the same error that says "Inside: error. Expecting list but getting text." Does this have to do with my report block—should I be using join instead of just reporting a list?

Right now you are reporting within the for loop, meaning that at the first iteration it will report some value. Rather, we can collect all the values in the form that we want to report at the end (a list in the case) and report it only when each value has been added to the list.

subject: question about connect 4 (final project)
content: Blayden and I were working on our connect 4 game, and were wondering if it was acceptable for us to create a list of all diagonals that would be updated each move with the corresponding item in the game board. Example below

Unfortunately, this is going to get marked down for style, and since one of your features is creating an algorithm that finds a winning move, this will likely not get full marks for that either.

This is because there is a lot of repetition in the code, which can be simplified into some sort of iterative solution. Think of it like you are performing a complex formula on 1000s of numbers: why write every step for every number when you can define a function and just feed entries into it?

I appreciate you're asking, since I understand it's likely because we did something similar in the Tic-Tac-Toe lab. That is because the lab is not meant to be super long, so writing out every combo of winning_triples helped shorten it.

I'll give the opportunity for readers @Kellyann Ye @Samhita Sen @Lam Pham  to weigh in as well.
I agree with Yolanda - we would mark down for style given so much repetition. Try to find a pattern to help you abstract the hard-coded numbers.

Yeah, both what Yolanda and Samhita said is correct! We want students in this class to ultimately learn good coding and project design habits, so that you can rely on them in the future, regardless of whether you continue to pursue cs. Ultimately, as teachers of a computer science, we'd vastly prefer that you put in the time to slowly figure out the pattern of winning sequences. But if this is a class you're taking without intending to continue in the CS track (or a CS-related track), and you're weighing algorithm-writing time vs final score on the project, you can keep it as-is, so long as you're aware you'll lose some style and feature points for it.

Our P/NP policy is that if you turn in all the assignments for the class and get credit for them, you will receive a Pass (if your grading option is P/NP). You can use your slip day for these assignments, but it would only work for 24 hrs after the original deadline.

subject: Final Exam Logistics
content:
Welcome to the Endgame!

This post contains information pertaining to the logistics of the final exam. Please read this post all the way through to get all the information.

  1. We will release a three-part, untimed, take-home final exam online using Gradescope on Saturday 8/15 @ 12:01am PDT. The three parts are (a) with Snap!  – a coding challenge, (b) with Python -- a coding challenge in Python, and (c) non-coding – the traditional non-coding exam, but delivered online. A PDF will be provided for the non-coding portion, and you will use Gradescope as an answer sheet.
    1. There is a 'Mock Non-Coding Final Exam' on Gradescope for you to try out this format.
  2. You will have 72 hours to complete it; it will be due by Monday 8/17 @ 11:59pm PDT. You may take as little or as much time as you need within this window. However, we do not anticipate this exam to take 72 hours. Expect to set aside ~6 hours to take this exam: 3 hours for the “in-lab” final (parts a and b), and 3 hours for the non-coding final (part c). 
    1. Note: the coding portion of the final will be significantly longer than the coding portion of the midterm, so please allocate time accordingly.
  3. You are to complete the final exam alone without consulting any other students or online resources except for coding when completing the Snap! & Python portions of the exam, and any handwritten notes you have taken prior to the start of the exam. You may not use Snap! Or Python for the non-coding portion of the exam. We will ask everyone to sign an attestation that they have upheld that policy when they submit their exam.
  4. You will be able to ask any clarifying questions by making a private post (Instructors Only) to a Piazza thread we will open up when we release the final. Our staff will respond and answer your questions as quickly as we can, and post the results back to you on Piazza and to a “clarifications” document on the online exam itself (so others will see them and not need to ask the same question).
  5. Testable material includes:
    1. All lectures not including guest lectures, social implications sessions, and the alumni panel.
    2. All problem sets.

We will make another post once the exam is released announcing its beginning and linking the clarification doc. In the meantime, some things to keep in mind:

  • The website resources page is a phenomenal study tool

  • If your score (percentage) on this exam is higher than the midterm, it will replace your midterm score per our “clobber” policy

  • We will be maintaining standards of academic integrity, so please follow the guidelines

CLARIFICATIONS:

I think there was a "non" forgot in this sentence: 

Note: the coding portion of the final will be significantly longer than the coding portion of the midterm, so please allocate time accordingly.

Is the coding portion longer or the non-coding portion longer?
the coding portion
Thank you!

Are we allowed to use handwritten notes during both the coding and non-coding portion of the final? Also, are we allowed to use all of the handwritten notes we've created, or is it possible for us to create a collective "cheat sheet" with our notes on it?

You are allowed to use ANY handwritten notes you've taken before Saturday on ALL THREE parts of the final. This means you can use old notes, but can NOT use a collective google doc (although you can make one before Sat and take down handwritten notes from that).
Okay, thank you!

subject: Spring 2020 Final
content: Hey! I was trying to solve the Final exam paper for Spring 2020. I don’t know which direction I’m supposed to tackle question 9 from. Am I supposed to read the descriptions of the blocks given in English and then choose the answers or am I supposed to look at how the blocks are written to choose the answers? I read the explanations for the answers and I don’t quite seem to understand why. Also, for question 10 d, I don’t understand how the answer is 103.

With these it's typically best to read the questions first so you know what is being asked of you. Then read the english version of the algorithms and use the snap blocks as clarification. These are notoriously tricky but they just take time and close attention.

10d is asking about the return value of mystery(100): "100999897969594...495969798999001". It's asking what is the smallest number that is not a substring of this. Notice how all numbers 1-100 are already in here. We saw that 101 is in there too in part (a), but then figuring out if 102 and 103 is in there takes some thought, but it turns out 103 is the smallest that is not in there.
