subject: Citing code
content: Hi there, someone mentioned during class that we are also supposed to cite whenever we use solutions from the web. How do we properly quote code? And what exactly would be considered intellectual property that requires citing in programming?
If we used code that was given to us in a past problem set, would we need to cite that code as well?
If you did not write the code, then yes. You could use the format "source: CS10 summer 2020 problem set x"
Got it, thank you!
Can we cite codes in the five major characteristics of the project? Will it be considered as lowering the level of complexity?

You can cite code in the *three* required features, however you must be careful that the code you cite is not doing all the work, it must be supplementary to the feature (like a helper block or something). If you are unsure you can always ask your TA.
If you copy and paste any code that you did not write yourself, you must cite it. A simple comment along the lines of "source: [source URL]" should do.

subject: Data Sci
content: Hey, I heard that the GPA cutoff for CS and Data Sci might be increased (I’m not very sure though). In the case that this happens, which students will be affected: students who haven’t declared yet or ...?

Not sure where you heard this information, but I am pretty sure it's false. 

If such a thing were to happen (very unlikely), it would only affect students who have not declared.

Oh well, I hope it's not true. I'm in this loop chat and Messenger chat where people are talking about it. I mean if it affects students who have not yet declared, then what happens to those who are so close to declaring Data Sci on a margin (say 2.3 GPA on the 2.0 cutoff)?
You'd probably still have to make the cutoff but as long as you're over you're good. I think there is an appeal process if you're like SUPER close but I'm not sure.
A 2.0 GPA is required for DS, but keep in mind that 2.0 is equivalent to passing your classes. Considering how new DS is, they are unlikely to create a cutoff higher than that.

subject: pset17
content:
Looks like my second if loop in add-genre does not work because if I add the same book multiple times, it will still add the title author even the title even author already exists. Could you help me with this please?

Thank you!

Consider line 27: you want to be careful with the brackets.

If you are checking for  ['honey, 'maxosb']  in  Book.varieties['Comic'], and  Book.varieties['Comic']  is  ['honey, 'maxosb'], what will that output?

In other words, will  ['honey, 'maxosb'] in ['honey, 'maxosb']  return True or False? Why?

Can I just check title in the key list to see whether it already exist?

Like:

for i in the range (0,len(Book.varieties[self.genre]):

     if Book.varieties[self.genre](i)==self.title:

             ..........

Look at the documentation for the function in the spec. Notice that for each genre we want a list, where each item is a list of the author and title (list of lists). Make sure that is worked into your implementation too :)

I'm not sure if this question is too specific to be answered for the exam. If that's the case, I completely understand. I just figured I would give it a shot.

For the algorithmic complexity questions (6.1-6.4), are we expected to consider the algorithm of the abstracted Snap! blocks? For example, in 6.1, it uses the x contains y block. I don't know the actual algorithm behind the block but I can make a good guess as to how it's supposed to work. However, because it's not shown on the script externally, I'm not sure if the inner workings should be considered for the exam. I ask because if I am, I would have to base my answer off of an assumed algorithm that's abstracted away from me. I just want to make sure I'm considering everything you want me to.

Thank you for your help!
You should consider the runtimes of the blocks used in the algorithms.

subject: Question Regarding Test Cases for With Snap! Exam
content:
Hi, 

The version of XML file I downloaded did not have test cases in the Test Case Sprite, is there any way I can import the test cases to the version I worked on without making the blocks again in the new file with test cases? 

Thanks!
Best choice is probably to export the blocks you worked on and import them into the file with the test cases.

subject: Non-coding section
content: Hey sorry if this is a stupid question, but I was wondering what the "independently" rule for the non-coding section means?  Does that mean I have to complete the entire non-coding section and submit prior to returning to my code in python?  Because I was planning on working on the non-coding for a bit and then switching between the sections to give myself a break from each section as I try to finish them.  Is this ok?  Sorry once again if this seems like an obvious question I just really don't want to cause any accidental problems for myself by misinterpreting that line.

Naturally when you do the in-lab portion of the exam you would be using a computer. So if you were doing both the in-lab and the non-coding sections together you'd technically be on a computer while doing the latter, which isn't allowed. It's a point to emphasize don't use the computer for the non-coding portion. As for switching between exams, I don't see anything wrong with that as long as you follow the previous sentence. Turn off or move away from the computer when you switch...

subject: Weird spacing in part 2 of the python portion because of a space in the __repr__ function.
content: Hi can we delete the space in between the quotation marks of the line children = " ".join([str(child) for child in self.children]) in the __repr__ function? I know the specs say we shouldn't change the code but whenever I run the test cases in the code it gives a space in between each letter of the child. For example, adding a child named Grace would report (Dan (G r a c e)). I've attached some pictures below showing the problem.
That line is fine, you need that space there. Try retracing back another step.

subject: Did the 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3 get cut off
content: Are the 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3 multiple choice parts cut off?
You choose from the 'OPTIONS' for each of them. So 3.1, 3.2 and 3.3 can be either A-F.

subject: With Python Exam Question
content:
For the With Python Exam, I was wondering whether the ages function had to match exactly what the tests were expecting?

I have two main questions. Firstly, does the order matter? For example:

Failed example:

    ages(some_fam)

Expected:

    {'adult': ['Maxson'], 'child': ['Aaron']}

Got:

    {'child': ['Aaron'], 'adult': ['Maxson']}

Would the latter be incorrect?

Secondly, does it matter if the expected result is {'adult': ['Maxson'], 'child': ['Aaron']}, but I get {'adult': ['Maxson'], 'child': ['Aaron'], 'teen': [], 'senior': []}? Or should the empty keys be removed? Thank you.
Great question! The order does not matter for the dictionary, but it should only include the ages with people in it.

subject: Noncoding Final Q9
content:
Hi Aaron!

I'm sorry for asking questions too frequently(sort of panic about the final lol). I want to clarify that in Q9, the prompt says we cannot use [::-1] or any built-in functions in Python. I guess we cannot use the built-in functions that can reverse a list? Functions like "len()", ".append()", and "isinstance()" can still be used, or we cannot use all built-in functions.

Thanks!
You are correct, just no built in lists that reverse a list, but the other ones you mentioned are okay.

subject: Binary secret message in the with Snap spec is incorrect
content:
Not sure how important this might be, but I thought I'd mention it.

I exported the blocks when I was done with the with Snap! final and then dragged them into a new Snap! workspace to make sure everything was still working. Since the global variables for key/secret were gone, I copy/pasted in the binary codes from the spec. The decoded message came out completely different and garbled. I ended up running the two different binary codes (the one that came with the starter file and the one in the spec pdf) through a word/character counter, and the two codes are different lengths (the spec message is 1 byte longer). As far as I can tell, the binary code in the spec has been frameshifted; if it was just one extra byte placed right between other correct bytes, there should just be one extra letter in the decoded message and everything else should be correct.

Hey Ailun,

This may be because you have an older version of the file, which has 33 instead of 32 bytes for one of the test cases. Please refer to the clarifications doc for that one.

Also, when exporting your blocks, make sure to also export ALL the available options (i.e. including the green/red ones, not just the grey blocks).

subject: FamilyTree.count_members(self) with recursion and iteration
content: I implemented FamilyTree.count_members(self) using recursion and iteration would this be alright?
You have to use recursion to implement the core of the function. I suppose if you found a way to use iteration also it might be okay but I would have to see the function.

subject: Question 9 on the non-coding final
content: The 'rules' to solve this question say that we are not allowed to use [::-1] or any other build-in python function, does this mean I can't use the len() function, range() function, or isinstance() function or is it only referring to any function that will automatically reverse a list. Also am I allowed to use the lambda function?
It is only referring to the built in functions that reverse a list, the other ones you mentioned are okay. And you can use lambdas.

subject: With-Python Clarification Questions
content:
Hello!

I had a question regarding the ages() function in the With-Python portion of the final.

My function works as it should, however, I made it so that the output will always be a dictionary in the order of child, teen, adult, then senior. It looks like the output examples given are placed in order of the members in the input list. Essentially, both our outputs have the same content, it's just that the order is a bit different. Because of this, the autograder says that the tests have failed. I'm wondering if this is acceptable or if I should adjust my algorithm to make it output exactly the same thing as the example outputs, including order?

Thanks!

Heather
The order of the dictionary does not matter, so as long as the key, value pairs are correct you are on the right track.

subject: With Snap! Exam Recursion Requirement
content: For the Snap! portion of the exam that requires us to use recursion in at least one of the blocks, if we used recursion for one of the helper blocks (that is ultimately included in one of the five main blocks), would that satisfy the requirement? Or is it only satisfied if one of the five main blocks directly uses recursion? Thank you.
A recursive helper block would do the trick as ling as it contributes to the solution of one of the blocks significantly.

subject: Clarification for the Snap! blocks.
content: Just to clarify for the Snap! portion do we need to use HOFs, iteration, and recursion for each and every block, or can we split them between each block. For example block 1 has recursion, block 2 has iteration, and block 3 has hofs.
The second option, you have to use each of them once split among the blocks.

subject: Good bye and good luck!
content:
Hello everyone!

As our summer together officially draws to a close, I just want to say a BIG thank you to everyone, from our incredibly passionate and dedicated course staff, to all you wonderful people that we've had the privilege to call students this summer. Admittedly, this is an especially bittersweet moment for me and Aaron given that this is probably the final class of CS10 we'll ever get to teach

—an experience we'll hold dearly in our hearts. Whether it was the little, funny interactions in chat during lectures, or being able to talk and help out some of you in labs and OH, there were many moments where everyone felt close despite being so far apart.

Before we part ways, I'd like to wish you all the best of luck as you continue (or begin!) your college experience. I'd like to remind you all that eight weeks ago, you came in with little to no experience in what programming was. Now, you know the principles that all of computer science is built on, as well as all the profound impact computing has transformed our world. Most importantly, with an understanding of both, you now have the potential to have an impact on our world as well. Whether or not you decide to continue to pursue computer science, remember that you do not need to be a computer scientist to code or to write a truly amazing program. As alumni of CS10, you know better than anyone that starting with nothing is completely okay because you are more than enough to get things going. Never forget this!

As always, feel free to reach out to me whenever you need. From building a website or app, teaching CS, starting a CS10 League of Legends team (okay maybe not this actually), or just to talk about anything + everything, my metaphorical zoom meeting room is always open. You can reach me at maxsonyang@berkeley.edu or Messenger.

Once again, good luck, good bye, and thank you for everything!

#pin

Thank you all so much for teaching this class! I learned a lot and had a really great time. Despite the long distance I felt like a part of this community. I am glad that I got to know the Berkeley mindset a little and, most importantly, the unique CS10 spirit! Thank you so much!

Thank you everyone for such an awesome semester!! Feel free to reach out to me as well aaronbaker@berkeley.edu (or aaron.jbaker@yahoo.com if they decide to take away my berkeley email). 

Good luck with everything!!!
